hedline.hl1: Rock Film By Crowe Will Open In Toronto

abstract.p: Cameron Crowe's new, still-untitled film will premiere at Toronto International Film Festival in September (S)

block.p: Cameron Crowe's new, still-untitled film, based on his own experiences as a young journalist traveling with a rock band in the early 1970's, will get its world premiere at this year's Toronto International Film Festival. It is among a handful of movies whose inclusion in the festival's 25th anniversary season, which runs from Sept. 7 to 16, was announced this week.

The Toronto festival has grown in recent years to become the top showcase for many of Hollywood's fall and holiday-season films. Its audiences get the first look at many of the movies that end up as Academy Award contenders. Last year, ''American Beauty'' was a festival highlight and went on to dominate the Oscars; other festival screenings included Norman Jewison's ''Hurricane'' and Lasse Hallstrom's ''Cider House Rules.''

Cameron Crowe's new, still-untitled film, based on his own experiences as a young journalist traveling with a rock band in the early 1970's, will get its world premiere at this year's Toronto International Film Festival. It is among a handful of movies whose inclusion in the festival's 25th anniversary season, which runs from Sept. 7 to 16, was announced this week.

The Toronto festival has grown in recent years to become the top showcase for many of Hollywood's fall and holiday-season films. Its audiences get the first look at many of the movies that end up as Academy Award contenders. Last year, ''American Beauty'' was a festival highlight and went on to dominate the Oscars; other festival screenings included Norman Jewison's ''Hurricane'' and Lasse Hallstrom's ''Cider House Rules.''

Piers Handling, the festival's director, announced that Mr. Crowe's film would be joined at this year's festival by ''Best in Show,'' a mock documentary from Christopher Guest about the world of dog shows; ''The Contender,'' a political drama from the writer-director Rod Lurie about a senator facing a sex scandal, starring Joan Allen and Gary Oldman; and ''The Luzhin Defense,'' Marleen Gorris's drama about an Italian chess player, based on a novel by Vladimir Nabokov.
''Stardom,'' Denys Arcand's drama about the skyrocketing career of a young model, starring Dan Aykroyd, Frank Langella and Jessica Pare, will be the opening-night attraction.
Mr. Crowe's film, his first since ''Jerry Maguire'' in 1996, stars Billy Crudup, Frances McDormand and Jason Lee. It is about a teenage boy sent on assignment by Rolling Stone magazine in 1973.

DreamWorks, the studio that used the Toronto festival as a springboard for ''American Beauty'' last year, plans a similar release pattern for Mr. Crowe's film, opening it in New York and Los Angeles on Sept. 15, less than a week after its Toronto premiere, and then expanding to major United States cities on Sept. 22 and to a wide release on Sept. 29.
